titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, Knowledge, Creativity and Freedom, Office of the Vice President, Office Files of Alison R. Bernstein
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Knowledge, Creativity and Freedom, Office of the Vice President, Office Files of Alison R. Bernstein FA573

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-02-01 01:06:03 -0500.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Knowledge, Creativity and Freedom, Office of the Vice President, Office Files of Alison R. Bernstein

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Minimal Processing has been conducted to establish basic intellectual and physical control of the material and assess immediate preservation and conservation needs. Material remains as received, in original folders and storage boxes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Primarily documents meetings, events, and initiatives as well as providing subject files, working files and publications.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in 7 series by file type.
Series III. African Higher Education Initiative, 2001-2007

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Dr. Alison Bernstein worked at the Ford Foundation from 1983 until 2010, with a break in the early 1990s to assume the position of Associate Dean of the Faculty at Princeton University. Bernstein started as a program officer in 1983, and she was named director of Education and Culture at the Foundation in 1992. Bernstein was later promoted to vice president of the Ford Foundation's Education, Creativity and Free Expression Program, later called called Creativity and Free Expression. In 2011, Bernstein left the Foundation to become the director of the Institute for Women's Leadership at Rutgers University.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Ford Foundation has title, copyright and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them.

The Rockefeller Archive Center has authority to grant permission to cite and publish material from the collection. Permission to publish extensive excerpts, or material in its entirety, will be referred to the Ford Foundation.
